qas.question: What is the most common Christian denomination in Thuringia?
How much of the Thuringia population is non-religious?

answers.text: Today over two thirds of the population

qas.question: Which church in the state has the largest amount of members?

answers.text: The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany

qas.question: How much of the Thuringia population are Catholic?
How many Jews live in Thuringia?
What is the least common Secular denomination in Thuringia?
How much of the Thuringia population is gone?

plausible_answers.text: The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany

qas.question: Which church in the state has the smallest amount of members?
How much of the Thuringia population reject Catholics?
How many Jews moved out of Thuringia?

context: Since the Protestant Reformation, the most prominent Christian denomination in Thuringia has been <a0_0><b5_0>Lutheranism<b5_0/><a0_0/>. During the GDR period, church membership was discouraged and has continued shrinking since the reunification in 1990. <a1_0>Today over <b6_0>two thirds of the population<b6_0/><a1_0/> is non-religious. <a2_0><b7_0>The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany<b7_0/><a2_0/> has had the largest number of members in the state, adhered to by 24.0% of the population in 2009. Members of the Catholic Church formed <a3_0><b8_0>7.8% of the population<b8_0/><a3_0/>, while 68.2% of Thuringians were non-religious or adhere to other faiths. The highest Protestant concentrations are in the small villages of southern and western Thuringia, whereas the bigger cities are even more non-religious (up to 88% in Gera). Catholic regions are the Eichsfeld in the northwest and parts of the Rhön Mountains around Geisa in the southwest. Protestant church membership is shrinking rapidly, whereas the Catholic Church is somewhat more stable because of Catholic migration from Poland, Southern Europe and West Germany. Other religions play no significant role in Thuringia. There are only a few thousand Muslims (largely migrants) and about <a4_0><b9_0>750<b9_0/> Jews<a4_0/> (mostly migrants from Russia) living in Thuringia. Furthermore, there are some Orthodox communities of Eastern European migrants and some traditional Protestant Free churches in Thuringia without any societal influence.
